scenesList.scene_18: New Zone-Based Pricing Model with Additional Service Fee

start.title:
SkyTrack's Pricing Dilemma

Exploring Piecewise Functions
start.description: Can you help Mira and Leo develop a fair pricing strategy for SkyTrack's medication delivery service to hard-to-reach areas? In this STEAMQuest, you'll explore how piecewise functions can create flexible pricing models tailored to the unique challenges of delivering essential medications to underserved regions.

intro.description:
Welcome to SkyTrack's Drone Delivery Service

Join us in revolutionizing medical delivery to hard-to-reach areas using advanced drone technology and smart pricing systems.
intro.mira_inform_leo: Leo, come take a look at this. We've just received requests from three new rural hospitals to join our medical delivery network.
intro.leo_meet_mira: That's fantastic! More communities getting access to critical medications. I'm really curious! What type of drones are we using for these deliveries? I feel like the kind of drone must play a big role here.
intro.mira_thinking: We use special hybrid drones that can take off like a helicopter but fly like a plane. They're great for quick deliveries up to 50 miles and can carry small packages easily. We're losing a lot of money on these long-distance deliveries, and I hate to say it, but our current pricing isn't working. The drones we use are great for delivering packages under 50 miles, but the farther we go, the higher the operational costs.
intro.leo_question: Aren't we charging based on distance?

skytrack-office.mira_explanation: We charge a $2 per mile fixed rate for deliveries. Our drones can fly up to 50 miles, but anything past 15 miles costs us more to operate - mostly due to battery life and weather risks. Most customers are within 15 miles anyway.
skytrack-office.mira_affirmation: Yes! And we also want to keep a flat fee for local deliveries less than 5 miles away to ensure nearby clinics and pharmacies have affordable access to critical medications.
skytrack-office.leo_response: That makes sense. So, beyond increasing our $2 per mile fixed rate for all customers, it should somehow get more expensive for customers beyond a certain range. Like, do we need a premium range?
skytrack-office.leo_question: A flat fee for local deliveries makes sense! But how do we connect that with pricing for longer distances in one function?

understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_solution: I'm thinking we can use a piecewise function. Let's break this down into zones. First, we want local deliveries up to 5 miles to be a flat $1.
understanding-piecewise-functions.medium_distance_explanation: Then for medium distances from 5 through 15 miles, we'll add $2 per mile...
understanding-piecewise-functions.long_distance_explanation: And finally, for long distances above 15 and up to 50 miles, we'll charge a premium rate of $4 per mile.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_confusion: Yikes. That looks more complicated than my morning coffee order! It's like three different functions in one. What's going on with those inequalities?
understanding-piecewise-functions.aunt_lily_confirm: Exactly! This is a linear function, where x is the input (number of shirts) and C (x) is the output (total cost). Let's play around with the numbers.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_visualization_request: Could we visualize this somehow? It's hard to keep track of all these zones.
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_zone_explanation_intro: That's what determines which function gets applied. Let me walk through this, one step at a time.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_flat_rate_understanding: So this is the flat fee. Whether it's 2 miles or 4 miles, we just charge $1.
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_text1: Exactly! Now let's look at what happens when deliveries go beyond 5 miles.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_zone2_calculation: Ok, let me think about that. We have a $1 base price, plus 8 miles at $2 each, that's $16 more. So the total comes to $17.
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_zone2_confirmation: Exactly. It's starting to get a bit pricey. Just wait for zone 3.
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_zone3_intro: Zone 3 is everything over 15 miles. That's premium pricing territory.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_17_miles_calculation: So, for a customer 17 miles away...
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_17_miles_calculation: We'd charge the base rate of $1, $30 for Zone 2, plus 17 miles at $4 each, which is $68. Ok, so the total comes to $99.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_zone3_concern: Yeah, that seems a little unfair to me. Maybe we can adjust so that there isn't such a big jump between different zones?
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_suggestion: Ok, good idea. If we want that, let's only charge per mile for the extra miles beyond 5.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_modified_example: Then a 6 mile delivery would be the $1 base fee and just another $2 for the extra mile. That seems much more reasonable.
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_revised_approach: Let's try out a new function then. We'd just need to subtract the initial 5 miles from the zone 2 pricing.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_premium_suggestion: And, for premium, I guess the higher rate should only apply to the miles beyond zone 2.
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_graph_suggestion: I think this is much more reasonable. Let's see this new zone-based pricing on a graph.
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_tool_intro: Here, I've prepared a tool to help us compare the pricing. Let's call our original pricing model “fixed-rate pricing”. We'll call the one we're considering now “zone-based pricing”.
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_tool_understanding: Ok, I'm able to adjust zone prices and visualize delivery costs using this tool.
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_customer_scenario: Try it out. With Zone 1 at $1 flat, Zone 2 at $2/mile, and Zone 3 at $4/mile, I just had a customer request a delivery 18 miles away. Can you calculate how much they paid?
understanding-piecewise-functions.leo_price_concern: Well that seems too pricey! Do you think customers might get annoyed by the jumps in the price?
understanding-piecewise-functions.mira_price_jump_example: I know what you mean. If I request a delivery that is 6 miles away, I'll be charged $12 more than a 5 mile delivery!

piecewise_function_calculator_equation.title: Piecewise Function Formula
piecewise_function_calculator_equation.formula_equation:
This model calculates pricing with:
P(d) = 
1,
0 < d ≤ 5
d is the distance, in miles, to the delivery destination
1 represents the $1 flat fee
P(d) is the pricing function for the delivery distance, in dollars
0 < d ≤ 5 shows that the function applies to deliveries up to the first 5 miles
piecewise_function_calculator_equation.formula_equation2:
Updated pricing model now includes additional range:
P(d) = {
1,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2d,
5 < d ≤ 15
d is equal to the delivery distance
1 is the $1 flat fee
P(d) is the pricing function for the delivery distance
0 < d ≤ 5 shows that the function applies for the first 5 miles
5 < d ≤ 15 shows that the function applies from 5 through 15 miles
piecewise_function_calculator_equation.formula_equation3:
Final update to pricing model includes third distance range:
P(d) = {
1,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2d,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 30 + 4d,
15 < d ≤ 50
d is equal to the delivery distance
1 is the $1 flat fee
P(d) is the pricing function for the delivery distance
0 < d ≤ 5 shows that the function applies for the first 5 miles
5 < d ≤ 15 shows that the function applies from 5 through 15 miles
15 < d ≤ 50 shows that the function applies from 15 through 50 miles
piecewise_function_calculator_equation.detailed_cost_function:
total costs = variable costs + fixed costs

\[{\color{#A6001A}{C(x)}} = {\color{#0055B2}10x} + {\color{#005F20}1000}\]
x is the number of T-shirts sold
10x is the variable cost ($10 per T-Shirt)
1000 is the fixed cost ($1000)
C (x) is the cost of x number of T-shirts
piecewise_function_calculator_equation.function_notation_info:
The function notation C (x) represents the cost function. It is not C multiplied by x.

In C (x) = 10x + 1000:
  • •x represents the number of shirts (the quantity), not dollars
  • •The fixed cost (1000) stays the same no matter how many shirts you make
  • •We could have named this function anything (like T (x) or F (x)) - using C just helps us remember it's cost

Remember: To find the total cost for any number of shirts, replace x with that number and calculate 10x + 1000.

about.heading: How Pricing Works
about.body:
This is a flat-rate pricing model for delivery services:
P(d) = $1.00
Where d is between 0-5 miles
  • Flat $1 rate applies for all deliveries up to 5 miles
  • Distance (d) is measured in miles from pickup to delivery location

zone1.title: Delivery Pricing Zones
zone1.description:
P(d) = 
{
1,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2d,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 30 + 4d,
15 < d ≤ 50
Zone 1 (0-5 miles):
Flat fee of $1 for any distance up to 5 miles
Example: A 3-mile delivery costs $1

zone2.title: Delivery Pricing Zones
zone2.description:
P(d) = 
{
1,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2d,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 30 + 4d,
15 < d ≤ 50
Zone 1 (0-5 miles):
Zone 2 (5-15 miles):
  • Base price: $1
  • Plus $2 per mile
Example: An 8-mile delivery
  • Base price: $1
  • Additional cost: 8 miles × $2 = $16
  • Total cost: $17

zone3.title: Delivery Pricing Zones
zone3.description:
P(d) = 
{
1,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2d,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 30 + 4d,
15 < d ≤ 50
Zone 1 (0-5 miles):
Zone 2 (5-15 miles):
Zone 3 (over 15 miles):
  • Base price: $1
  • Zone 2 charge: $30 (for miles 5-15)
  • Plus $4 per mile beyond 15 miles
Example: A 17-mile delivery
  • Base price: $1
  • Zone 2 charge: $30
  • Additional distance: 17 miles × $4 = $68
  • Total cost: $99

formula-aria-label-parts.part1: P of d defined as follows: P of d equals
formula-aria-label-parts.part2: for 0 less than d less than or equal to 5; P of d equals
formula-aria-label-parts.part4: times d for 5 less than d less than or equal to 15; P of d equals
formula-aria-label-parts.part5: times d for 15 less than d less than or equal to 50.

planning.planning_body:
Okay, let's see!

We have two options to work on this. Exploring both will provide a better understanding.

section_header.title: Market Update
section_header.description: CompeteDrone introduces a $2 service fee on all deliveries.

competitor_analysis.mira_observation: We just got a market update! Our competitor just added a $2 service fee to all deliveries. We should analyze how this kind of change affects pricing.
competitor_analysis.leo_reaction: A service fee? That's an interesting twist. I wonder how that affects our pricing model.
competitor_analysis.mira_opportunity: Actually, this is perfect timing. We can use our piecewise function knowledge to understand exactly how service fees impact pricing across all distances.
competitor_analysis.mira_analysis: Let's explore how an additional service fee affects pricing across all zones.

service_fee_analysis.leo_equation:
So... if we add
z = $2
service fee.
The base price becomes
1 + z
The middle zone becomes
1 + 2(d − 5) + z
The premium zone becomes
1 + 20 + 4(d − 15) + z

service_fee_formula.complete_formula:
This model calculates pricing with:
P(d) = {
1 + z,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2(d − 5) + z,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 20 + 4(d − 15) + z,
15 < d ≤ 50
d is equal to the delivery distance
z is the additional service fee
P(d) is the pricing function for the delivery distance
0 < d ≤ 5 shows that the function applies for the first 5 miles
5 < d ≤ 15 shows that the function applies from 5 miles through 15 miles
15 < d ≤ 50 shows that the function applies from 15 miles through 50 miles
service_fee_formula.mira_explanation: Let's write out our complete function with the additional service fee z.

about.heading: Understanding the Formula
about.body:
Variables:
P(d)
: Pricing function for delivery.
d
: Distance traveled in miles.
z
: Additional service fee.
Zone Breakdown:
Zone 1 (0-5 miles)
Base rate + fee
1 + z
Zone 2 (5-15 miles)
Base rate + $2 per mile over 5 miles + fee
1 + 2(d-5) + z
Zone 3 (over 15 miles)
Base rate + $20 + $4 per mile over 15 miles + fee
1 + 20 + 4(d-15) + z

service_fee_formula.leo_understanding: Oh! I see the pattern now. z gets added to every zone's expression. That means the service fee increases the total price, no matter the distance!

service_fee_calculator.mira_question: Let's analyze this using the tool. If the competitor's $2 service fee is applied across all zones, how does that impact our pricing model?
service_fee_calculator.leo_observation: The base pricing for local deliveries increases $2, so $1 + $2 would be a $3 price. And it pushes up medium-range and long-distance deliveries by the same $2 too.
service_fee_calculator.mira_confirmation: Exactly! This demonstrates a vertical shift in the graph. Can you calculate the new cost for a 12-mile delivery with the $2 service fee?
service_fee_calculator.leo_calculation: So, after the service fee, the 12-mile delivery cost jumps by $2. It's consistent across all distances.
service_fee_calculator.mira_hypothesis: The service fee creates a vertical shift. What would happen if z was $0?
service_fee_calculator.leo_realization: Oh! Then both graphs would be exactly the same - they'd overlap!
service_fee_calculator.mira_praise: You're getting really good at this!
service_fee_calculator.heading: New Zone-Based Pricing Model with Additional Service Fee
service_fee_calculator.body: Where d represents the delivery distance in miles

about.heading: Pricing Comparison: Vertical Shift
about.body:
New Pricing Model With Service Fee
z
When a constant service fee
z
is added to each delivery, it shifts the entire pricing function upward by
z
units. For example, if
z = 2
(a $2 service fee), each zone's expression is adjusted to include this additional cost:
P(d) = {
1 + 2,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2(d - 5) + 2,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 20 + 4(d - 15) + 2,
15 < d ≤ 50

help.heading: Pricing with Service Fee
help.body:
Adjust the Service Fee:
  • Use the input box to set the service fee z
Calculate Delivery Costs for a Given Distance:
Using the adjusted model, calculate the cost:
  • Determine which zone the distance falls into
  • Apply the respective pricing expression, adding the service fee z to the base cost

graph.ariaLabel: Graph showing comparison of base model and service fee model.

heavy_package_pricing.header: Drone Battery Consumption During Flight
heavy_package_pricing.leo_concern: Mira, I've been noticing that heavier packages are draining our resources faster. Shouldn't we account for weight in our pricing model?
heavy_package_pricing.mira_agreement: That's a good point. Right now, we're only charging based on distance. But weight directly impacts our costs, especially for fuel and battery efficiency.
heavy_package_pricing.leo_question: So, what are you thinking? A flat fee for weight, or should we tie it to the distance zones?

enhance_pricing_model.formula:
This model calculates pricing with:
P(d,w)
 
=
{
1 + 2w,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2(d - 5) + 3w,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 20 + 4(d - 15) + 4w,
15 < d ≤ 50
d is equal to the delivery distance
w is the weight of the package to be delivered
P(d,w)
is the pricing function that depends on both delivery distance and weight
0 < d ≤ 5 shows that the function applies for the first 5 miles
5 < d ≤ 15 shows that the function applies from 5 miles through 15 miles
15 < d ≤ 50 shows that the function applies from 15 miles through 50 miles
enhance_pricing_model.mira_proposal:
I think we can combine the two.
  • For local deliveries under 5 miles, let's add $2 per pound to the base flat fee
  • For mid-range deliveries, we'll add $3 per pound
  • And for long-distance deliveries between 15-50 miles, we'll charge $4 per pound
  • The heavier the package, the higher the surcharge in each zone
enhance_pricing_model.leo_feedback: I like it. But do you think it's easy for customers to understand this pricing? I can imagine the breakdown getting complicated if we don't make it transparent.

about.heading: Understanding the Formula
about.body:
Zone 1
Base rate plus weight factor (
1 + 2w
) for 0-5 miles
Zone 2
Base rate plus $2 per mile over 5 miles plus weight factor (
1 + 2(d - 5) + 3w
) for 5-15 miles
Zone 3
Base rate plus $20 for zone2 plus $4 per mile over 15 miles plus weight factor (
1 + 20 + 4(d - 15) + 4w
) for
d > 15

dual_factor_price_calculator.mira_tool_explanation: That's why we have this tool. It lets us calculate and visually explain the costs to customers, step by step.
dual_factor_price_calculator.leo_understanding: Ok, so we need to now collect both weight and distance charges from our customers.
dual_factor_price_calculator.mira_enthusiasm: Yes! And this is where it gets exciting. We're not just calculating charges - we're optimizing resources, saving energy, and making delivery accessible to everyone.
dual_factor_price_calculator.mira_challenge: How much should we charge for an 8-lb package delivery at an 18-mile distance?
dual_factor_price_calculator.leo_calculation:
Alright, so for an 18-mile delivery with an 8-pound package, the tool shows:
  • $1 for the base fee,
  • $2 per mile for the mid-range distance in Zone 2,
  • $4 per mile for the extra 3 miles in Zone 3,
And $32 for the weight surcharge in Zone 3. That makes the total $65. That actually makes sense when you see it all broken down!
dual_factor_price_calculator.mira_confirmation: Exactly. The tool helps clarify how each part, distance and weight, contributes to the total cost. It ensures transparency for us and for the customers.
dual_factor_price_calculator.leo_realization: Wait... so we're actually...creating a sustainable delivery system.

about.heading: Combined Distance and Weight Based Pricing:
about.body:
New Weight-based Pricing Model is defined as follows:
P(d,w) = {
1 + 2w,
d ≤ 5
1 + 2(d - 5) + 3w,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 20 + 4(d - 15) + 4w,
15 < d ≤ 50
where,
d
= distance (in miles)
w
= weight (in pounds)

help.heading: How to use this tool
help.body:
The graphs provide separate pricing for distance-based and weight-based costs. To determine the total price, you'll need to combine both values.
Enter the delivery distance (in miles) and the package weight (in pounds) in the input boxes, then click "Calculate." The tool will display the separate prices for distance-based and weight-based costs.
The Total Price will be the sum of the distance-based price and the weight-based surcharge.

distance-base-price-calculator.mira_cost_question: Now, can you calculate the new delivery cost for an 18 mile delivery?
distance-base-price-calculator.leo_price_observation: Oh, we brought down the long-delivery price while keeping it fair and profitable.
distance-base-price-calculator.mira_praise: Great work figuring out our distance-based pricing, Leo! But look at these new challenges…

outro.leo_text_1: You know what's amazing? When we started, I thought this was just about making the business profitable.
outro.mira_text_1: That's often how great solutions start! But mathematics helps us see the bigger picture and ensure we're being fair to our customers.
outro.leo_text_2: I see that now. Whether it's fair pricing zones, handling service fees, or optimizing for heavy packages, it's all about ensuring we can deliver medications to the people who need them most, especially in hard-to-reach areas.
outro.mira_text_2: Exactly! And that's what successful businesses do - they solve real problems for real people.
outro.leo_text_3: So we're not just crunching numbers... we're building something that matters.
outro.mira_text_3: That's right. Next time someone asks why math matters, you can tell them about the time you helped build a fairer delivery system!

zone1.title: Zone1 (0-5 miles)
zone1.label: Adjust the slider to match the flat fee for the first 5 miles.

zone2.title: Zone2 (5-15 miles)
zone2.label: Adjust the slider to match the per mile rate for Zone 2.

zone3.title: Zone3 (15-50 miles)
zone3.label: Adjust the slider to match the per mile rate for Zone 3.

graph.ariaLabel: Graph showing comparison of old price and new price

about.heading: Piecewise Function for Distance-Based Pricing
about.body:
Each zone has a unique pricing rule based on the distance:
  • Zone 1 (0 < d ≤ 5): Flat fee of $1 for distances from 0 to 5 miles
  • Zone 2 (5 < d ≤ 15): Base price of $1 plus $2 per mile between 5-15 miles
  • Zone 3 (15 < d ≤ 50): Base price of $1, an additional $30 for Zone 2, and $4 per mile between 15-50 miles
The pricing function P(d) is represented in piecewise notation:
P(d) = {
1,
0 ≤ d ≤ 5
1 + 2d,
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 30 + 4d,
15 < d ≤ 50

help.heading: Pricing for 18-mile Distance
help.body:
Set Prices for Each Zone:
  • Use the sliders at the top to set the per-mile rate for Zone 2 (5-15 miles) and Zone 3 (15+ miles)
  • Zone 1 (0-5 miles) has a flat fee, which you can also adjust with its slider
Visualize How Pricing Changes with Distance:
  • As you adjust the rates, observe how the piecewise function graph updates to reflect the new pricing structure
  • Use the graph to find the price for an 18-mile delivery

distance_based_pricing_comparison.heading: Distance Based Price Comparison
distance_based_pricing_comparison.body: Where d represents the delivery distance in miles

graph.ariaLabel: Graph showing comparison of original price and new price

about.heading: Pricing Comparison
about.body:
The New Zone-Based Price smooths out price jumps by charging only for the miles beyond each zone boundary:
P(d)={
1,
0 < d ≤ 5
1 + 2(d - 5),
5 < d ≤ 15
1 + 20 + 4(d - 15),
15 < d ≤ 50
  • Zone 1 (0 to 5 miles): Flat fee of $1
  • Zone 2 (5 to 15 miles): Base price of $1 plus $2 for each mile beyond 5
  • Zone 3 (over 15 miles): Base price of $1, plus $20 for Zone 2, and $4 for each mile beyond 15

help.heading: Pricing for 18-mile Distance
help.body:
Analyze the Cost Impact:
  • Observe how the New Zone-Based Price results in a lower cost compared to the Original Model for much of Zone 2 and Zone 3
  • The New Model creates smoother transitions in cost as distance increases, reducing sharp jumps between zones
Using Graph to find Price
Interact with the graph and observe the price when d = 18 (where d represents distance in miles) for both the new and old pricing models.

delivery_price_calculator.heading: Dual Factor Price Calculator
delivery_price_calculator.explanation: where d = distance (miles), w = weight (lbs)

drone_battery_consumption_during_flight.formula: Battery Consumption = 0.5% × √weight

quest_completion.subheading: You Explored Pricing Strategies with Piecewise Functions!
quest_completion.content:
You've successfully completed the SkyTrack's Pricing Dilemma STEAMQuest.

  • •You used piecewise functions to create fair and sustainable delivery pricing zones
  • •You applied vertical shifts with service fees to analyze competitive models
  • •You combined distance and weight for balanced pricing in delivering critical medications to remote areas

Keep exploring the power of math in designing smart and flexible pricing systems!

revenue.definition: Revenue is the total amount of money earned from selling goods or services.

linear_functions.definition: A linear function is a function whose graph is a line.

Linear_functions.definition: A linear function is a function whose graph is a line.

break_even_point.definition: Break-even point is where your revenue is equal to your costs - you are not losing money, but you are not making money yet either.

profit.definition: Profit is the extra money a business makes after paying all its costs.

flat_fee.definition: Flat fee is a fixed price charged, meaning the cost does not vary based on usage, time, or amount.

common.x_units_y_dollars_label: where x is the number of units, C (x) is the total amount and R (x) is the revenue in dollars
common.invalid_input_submitted: One or more inputs are invalid!

common.mira_description: A female teacher with shoulder-length hair, wearing glasses, a dark blue business suit, and a black top. She has a name tag around her neck and is holding a tablet in her hands.
common.bg1_description: Modern lobby with glass walls, digital screen, and minimalistic design.
common.bg2_description: Futuristic control room with large windows, multiple screens, and drone.
common.bg3_description: Modern workspace with large monitor, digital map, and plants.
common.bg4_description: Sunset view from rooftop with drones flying over cityscape.
common.bg5_description: A futuristic building courtyard with a hovering drone and greenery.
